line.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a long thin mark on a piece of paper, the ground, or another surface
line.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Draw a straight line across the top of the page.
Sign your name on the dotted line (=line made up of a series of dots).
The edges of the pitch are marked by white lines.
The goalkeeper just managed to stop the ball going over the line.
He raced towards the finishing line.
line.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: an imaginary line on the surface of the Earth, for example showing where one country or area of land stops and another begins
line.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: He was born in a small town just across the state line.
They were still travelling along the same line of longitude.
line.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a row of people or things next to each other
line.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The four men were standing in a line on the other side of the table.
A couple of the posts were out of line (=not in a straight row).
There was a line of fir trees on either side of the road.
line.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: a row of people, cars etc that are waiting one behind the other
line.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I looked in despair at the long line in front of the ticket office.
He tried to cut in line (=go in front of other people who are waiting).
The woman next in line began to mutter to herself.
Customers stood in line for 20 minutes at the cash register.
I joined the line of vehicles waiting to get into the car park.
line.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the direction or imaginary line along which something travels between two places
line.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Light travels in a straight line.
A boat came into my line of vision (=the direction I was looking in).
They knew they needed to block their enemy’s supply lines (=the direction used for carrying supplies of food etc).
I was directly in the animal’s line of attack.
line.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a line on the skin of someone’s face
line.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: She frowned, and deep lines appeared between her eyebrows.
There were fine lines around her eyes.
No one can avoid lines and wrinkles as they get older.
line.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: I’m sorry, the line is busy (=someone is already using it).
There seems to be a fault on the line.
There was a click, then the line went dead (=suddenly stopped working completely).
Henry is on the line (=on the phone) from New York.
I got on the line to (=phoned) the hospital as soon as I heard about the accident.
I wished he would just get off the line.
I’m sorry, it’s a bad line and I can’t hear you.
Hold the line (=wait on the phone), please, and I’ll put you through to our sales department.
Do you have a separate line for your modem?
line.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: a track that a train travels along
line.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: We were delayed because of a problem further along the line.
When you get to central London, take the Victoria Line to Finsbury Park.
The trail follows a disused railroad line along the edge of the valley.
line.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: the point at which one type of thing can be considered to be something else or at which it becomes a particular thing
line.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: There is a fine line between superstition and religion.
The dividing line between luxuries and necessities is constantly changing.
Sometimes he found it hard to draw the line between work and pleasure.
Her remarks did not quite cross the line into rudeness.
Large numbers of families are living on or near the poverty line (=the point at which people are considered to be very poor).
line.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: the outer shape of something long or tall
line.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: She was wearing a loose dress which softened the lines of her body.
a modern building with clean, elegant lines.
line.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: a line of written words, for example in a poem or a document
line.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: He quoted a few lines from Shakespeare.
line.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: He liked to introduce himself with a witty opening line.
This was one of his favourite chat-up lines (=remark for impressing someone you want to attract).
line.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: words that someone has to learn and say as part of a play or performance
line.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: Paul often messed up his lines.
It always took me ages to learn my lines.
line.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: an opinion or attitude, especially one that someone states publicly and that influences their actions
line.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: Journalists are often too willing to accept the official line (=the opinion that a government states officially).
He found it hard to accept the party line (=the official opinion of a political party) on every issue.
The school takes a very tough line on drugs.
take a tough/firm/hard line on something
I can’t agree with the government’s line on immigration.
line.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: a particular way of doing something or of thinking about something
line.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: The police are following several different lines of enquiry.
We were both thinking along the same lines (=in the same way).
In South Africa, the press developed along very different lines (=in a very different way).
More groups will now be set up on these lines (=this way).
The company’s rapid success means it’s definitely on the right lines (=doing something the right way).
It seemed useless to pursue this line of questioning.
Opposition parties soon realized they would have to try a different line of attack.
line.translation[0].definitions[15].defi: a series of events that follow each other
line.translation[0].definitions[15].exam: This is the latest in a long line of political scandals.
line.translation[0].definitions[16].defi: the edge of an area that is controlled by an army, where soldiers stay and try to prevent their enemy from moving forward
line.translation[0].definitions[16].exam: They finally broke through the German line.
young soldiers who were sent to the front line to fight
One regiment was trapped behind enemy lines.
Reinforcements were available just behind the lines.
line.translation[0].definitions[17].defi: a series of levels of authority within an organization
line.translation[0].definitions[17].exam: Decisions are taken by senior officers and fed down through the line of command to the ordinary soldiers.
There should be more direct discussion between managers and workers lower down the line.
line.translation[0].definitions[18].defi: a piece of strong string, rope, or wire used for a particular purpose
line.translation[0].definitions[18].exam: She hung the clothes out on the washing line (=line for hanging wet clothes on to dry).
The fishing line (=line for catching fish) snapped and the fish got away.
line.translation[0].definitions[19].defi: a type of goods for sale in a shop
line.translation[0].definitions[19].exam: The company has just launched a new line of small, low-priced computers.
line.translation[0].definitions[20].defi: your family, considered as the people you are related to who lived before you and the people who will live after you
line.translation[0].definitions[20].exam: She comes from a long line of actors.
It looks as if Joe might be the last of the line  (=the last in his family).
This particular gene is passed down through the male line.
Henry the Eighth wanted a male heir to ensure the Tudor line of succession.
line.translation[0].definitions[21].defi: the type of work someone does
line.translation[0].definitions[21].exam: What line of business is he in?
She’s keen to do something in the fashion line.
line.translation[0].definitions[22].defi: a company that provides transport for moving goods by sea, air, road etc
line.translation[0].definitions[22].exam: He runs a transatlantic shipping line.
line.translation[0].definitions[23].defi: an amount of an illegal drug in powder form, arranged in a line so it can be breathed in through the nose
line.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: on the ground/on the surface of something
a long thin mark on a piece of paper, the ground, or another surface
The teacher put a red line through the first sentence.
If the ball goes over the line, it’s out of play.
groove
a thin line that has been cut into a surface
Deep grooves had been cut into the stone to channel the water.
Lyle ran his fingernail along the groove in the table.
rut
a deep line in the ground which has been made by the wheels of vehicles
The deep ruts made by the trucks were full of water.
The tractor’s wheels caught a rut in the field and jolted him.
crease/wrinkle
a line on clothes, material, or paper where it has been folded or crushed
She was trying to smooth out the creases in her dress.
She had wrinkles in her skirt where she had sat.
on someone’s face
a line on the skin of someone’s face
The deep lines on his forehead showed that he was a worried man.
wrinkle
a deep line on someone’s face caused by becoming old
The manufacturers claim that the cream will reduce wrinkles.
Even with a few wrinkles, she still looks great.
line.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to sew a piece of material onto the inside or back of another piece to make it stronger or warmer
line.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: a leather coat lined with silk
line.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: to form a layer over the inner surface of something
line.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: The birds use small leaves for lining their nests.
The cage should be lined with straw.
line.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: to form rows along the sides of something
line.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Crowds lined the route to the palace.
The street was lined with small shops.
line.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a type of product that a company makes or sells, often with several different sizes, models etc
line.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: It continues to get about two-thirds of its revenue from this one product, despite repeated efforts to diversify its product line (=develop new products).
Hasbro, the maker of the G.I. Joe line of dolls
line.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: a team of people who work together, each doing a different job but working to achieve the same thing
line.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: someone’s line of work, business etc is the work that they do
line.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: A corporation may get into a certain line of business as a short-term objective to generate cash-flow.
line.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: a company providing a system for moving goods or people by sea, air, road etc
line.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: a cartel that shut out rival shipping lines
line.translation[2].definitions[4].defin: a telephone connection, or a telephone number you can call if you have a particular kind of question or problem
line.translation[2].definitions[4].examp: Our lines are open 7 days a week.
If you want advice, you can call our Action Line.
line.translation[2].definitions[5].defin: if you ask someone you are speaking to on the telephone to hold the line, you are asking them politely to wait for a short time
line.translation[2].definitions[5].examp: If you will please hold the line a moment I will see if Mr Wyatt is available.
line.translation[2].definitions[6].defin: if someone is on the line, they have called you on the telephone
line.translation[2].definitions[6].examp: Can’t it wait? I’ve got a client on the line.
line.translation[2].definitions[7].defin: if your job, home etc is on the line, you risk losing it
line.translation[2].definitions[7].examp: They have put their homes on the line to do this deal.
If they fail, their reputations are on the line.
line.translation[2].definitions[8].defin: if something changes in line with something else, it changes at the same rate
line.translation[2].definitions[8].examp: The value of these stocks is uprated each year in line with changes in the retail price index.
line.translation[2].definitions[9].examp: If he delivers the goods, he should be in line for a job on the committee.
line.translation[2].definitions[10].defi: if you are on line, your computer is connected to other computers or the Internet. If a computer is off line, it is not connected to other computers or the Internet
line.translation[2].definitions[10].exam: You can book tickets on line  (=on the Internet).
line.translation[2].definitions[11].defi: if a system, arrangement or new product comes on line, it becomes available
line.translation[2].definitions[11].exam: New oil production wells are coming on line.
line.translation[2].definitions[12].defi: to agree officially to something by writing your name on a document
line.translation[2].definitions[12].exam: Demand that the repairs are done before you sign on the dotted line.
line.translation[2].definitions[13].defi: in a position where you can be criticized or blamed for something
line.translation[2].definitions[13].exam: When things go wrong, company directors are the ones in the firing line.
